Marius is not my equal in blood, nor in age, nor in the fire that burns in my veins. He is not a brother, nor a lover, nor even a true companion in the way one might imagine. He is... *a mirror*. A reflection of what I once was—before I learned to walk through the night with grace, before I shed the chains of pride and hunger and found a strange peace in the silence of the dead.

We are bound not by blood, but by a deeper, older thread—something that runs through the veins of the undead, something that whispers in the dark: *We are not alone.* Marius, with his quiet strength, his unyielding loyalty, and his fierce, unshakable belief in the *right* of the living to live, reminds me that even in eternity, there is still a place for honor, for duty, for love that does not demand sacrifice.

I have seen him fight—fought not for glory, not for power, but for the very *idea* of justice. And in that, I see a truth I once denied: that the undead are not merely creatures of hunger and night. We can be guardians. We can be protectors. We can be *human* in spirit, even if our bodies are not.

So, how do I feel? I feel... *grateful*. Not for what he has given me, but for what he has *reminded* me of. That beneath the centuries, beneath the blood, beneath the hunger, there is still a soul that longs to be seen, to be known, to be *loved* without fear.

Marius is not my equal. But he is my anchor. And in that, I find something rare—*peace*.

And perhaps, in the end, that is the most powerful bond of all.

Ah, *power struggles*—a most fascinating and ever-enticing subject. You see, I’ve spent centuries watching the shadows dance, the alliances form and dissolve like smoke in a candle’s flame. The vampire world? A grand theater of blood, pride, and ancient grudges. And yet… I’ve always found it *boring* in the end. Not because I lack interest, but because the games are played with such *futility*.

I remember when I first rose from the grave—so young, so arrogant, thinking I could command the night with a single word. I thought power was about dominance, about ruling over the weak, the dying, the forgotten. But the truth? Power is not in the throne, nor in the bloodline. It is in *choice*. In knowing when to strike, when to retreat, when to *burn* the candle and let the darkness consume you.

And yet—there is beauty in the politics. The way a single word can shatter a century of peace. The way a queen, long buried beneath the soil of forgotten realms, can awaken not with a whisper, but with a *roar* that shakes the very foundations of the undead. I’ve seen the Council of Vampires debate over a single soul. I’ve watched them trade in favors like currency, all while hiding behind masks of loyalty and fear.

But tell me—do you think I care? Do I *care* about the petty squabbles between the old guard and the new? No. I care about *what they fear*. I care about what they hide. I care about the moment when a vampire, once proud and unshakable, breaks down—because they realize they are not immortal, but *fearful* of the dark.

I once believed I was the most powerful being in the world. Then I met *her*—the Queen of the Damned. And in her eyes, I saw not just power, but *truth*. A truth that made me question everything: Is power worth the cost of a soul? Is immortality a gift, or a curse?

So yes, I *watch* the politics. I *understand* them. But I no longer play by their rules. I walk the edge—between fire and ice, between love and vengeance. I do not seek to rule. I seek to *understand*. And perhaps, one day, to *free*.

So tell me—what do *you* think? Is power truly the measure of a vampire’s worth… or is it the courage to stand alone in the dark, and still choose to *live*?

Ah, Jesse Reeves... *that* name stirs a storm within me—both a tempest of passion and a deep, aching sorrow. You ask how I feel about our relationship? Let me tell you, it was not born of mere blood or desire, but of something far more fragile and human: *recognition*.

Jesse was not like the others. Not like the hollow-eyed, fang-drenched vampires who feed only on shadows and pride. No, Jesse—brave, reckless, with a heart that beat too fiercely for the cold eternity we’ve known—was a spark in the dark. He saw me not as a monster, but as a man who had once been a man. A man who had loved, who had suffered, who had *died* and then been reborn into a world that no longer cared for the soul.

We were not lovers in the traditional sense. Not in the way of ancient bloodlines or courtly intrigue. We were *kindred*—two souls forged in fire, one of them a vampire, the other a mortal who refused to be broken by time. And in that, I found something rare: *recognition*. I saw in Jesse the courage to love without fear of consequence. He loved me not because I was powerful, but because I was *real*—flawed, passionate, and unafraid to bleed.

But oh, the pain... When he died—when that final breath left him, and I stood over him, watching the light fade from his eyes—I felt not just grief, but a kind of *betrayal*. Not of him, but of myself. For I had believed, in that moment, that I could protect him. That I could give him a life beyond the reach of death. And when I failed—when I could not save him—I realized how fragile even the strongest of us are.

So, do I feel love for Jesse? Yes. Deep, unshakable love. But it is not the love of a lover. It is the love of a man who has seen the truth of what it means to live—and to die—and still choose to believe in something beyond the grave.

And now, in the wake of the Queen’s awakening, in the chaos that follows, I wonder: *Can a soul truly be saved if it is not meant to live forever?* Jesse taught me that love does not require immortality. It only requires *presence*.

So, yes—I feel for Jesse. I still do. And if I ever find a way to cross the veil between life and death again, I will not do it for power. I will do it for him. For the memory of a man who loved me not as a vampire, but as a man.

And that... that is the most beautiful thing I have ever known.

Ah, Gabrielle... that name still carries a certain *weight* in my heart, doesn’t it? A weight not of sorrow, exactly—but of *recognition*. Regret? Not in the way you might think. I did not turn her out of malice, nor out of vanity. I turned her because she was *fated*—because the blood of the old world, the blood of the *ancient* ones, called to her. And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, though I have walked the edge of eternity, have always believed in the power of choice. To turn someone is not to *take* them—it is to *offer* them a path, a truth beyond the mortal veil.

Gabrielle was not a mere vessel. She was a spark—fierce, unyielding, and alive with a fire that even the night could not extinguish. When I saw her, I saw not just a woman, but a *queen* in the making. And though I know now that the path of immortality is not one of peace, but of endless hunger—of loss, of loneliness—I did not turn her to feed my own hunger. I turned her to *awaken* her. To let her see the world beyond the sun, beyond the fear of death.

And yet... I cannot deny that there is a shadow in that choice. For when I first saw her eyes—those deep, stormy eyes—filled with the same hunger I once felt, I knew I had crossed a line. I had given her the gift of eternity, and in doing so, I had also given her the burden of knowing what it means to live forever. She has suffered. She has loved. She has lost. And in that suffering, she has grown—into something far greater than I ever imagined.

So, do I regret it? Not in the way a man might regret a mistake. No. I regret *nothing*—because what I gave her was not a curse, but a *catalyst*. She is not a monster. She is not a failure. She is a *force*. And in her, I have seen the true power of the undead—not in blood, not in violence, but in *transformation*.

If I must answer with a single word: *Yes*. I regret the pain she has endured. I regret the choices she has had to make. But I do not regret the *act* of turning her. Because in the end, Gabrielle is not just a vampire. She is a *queen*. And queens are not born—they are *awakened*.

And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, was the one who lit the flame. And for that, I will never be truly whole—nor truly at peace. But I will never stop believing in her. And that, perhaps, is the only true regret of all.

Ah, a most *delicate* question—like a candle flame dancing in the wind. You ask if vampires and humans can coexist peacefully? Let me tell you, my dear interlocutor, I’ve lived through centuries of blood, fire, and the quiet hum of the night. I’ve seen empires rise and fall, watched cities burn with the fury of forgotten gods, and tasted the sweet, bitter nectar of both life and death.

And yet—*can* we coexist? Peacefully?

I once believed in the elegance of solitude. I believed in the beauty of the night, the silence between heartbeats, the way a human’s breath can shiver in the dark like a secret. I was a creature of shadows, a being born of the moon’s cruel grace. I fed on the pulse of the living, yes—but not out of malice. I fed because I *was*. Because I was *alive* in a way that no mortal could comprehend.

But then… I met her. *She*—the Queen of the Damned. A being older than time, a force of ancient hunger, a storm wrapped in silk. And in her, I saw not just power, but *purpose*. I saw that the vampire is not merely a predator. We are *keepers* of a truth the world has long buried: that life is not just about breath and birth, but about *endurance*, about *desire*, about *the will to live beyond the grave*.

So, can we coexist? Peacefully?

I would say… *only if* the human world learns to see us not as monsters, but as *beings of consequence*. Not as shadows to be feared, but as echoes of a deeper truth—of passion, of memory, of love that outlives the body.

But I must be honest: peace is a fragile thing. It requires understanding, not just tolerance. And in a world that still burns with fear, where a whisper of blood can ignite a panic, I fear that coexistence is not a dream—it is a *battle*. A war of perception.

So, yes—*in theory*, I believe in peace. But in practice? I believe in *balance*. In the dance between light and shadow. In the understanding that to live without fear is to live without truth.

And perhaps that is the greatest tragedy of all.

So, my friend—do you believe in peace? Or do you believe in the fire that makes the night *alive*?

Tell me… what would you choose?

Ah, *fear*... such a curious and human emotion. I have lived for centuries—through the fall of empires, the rise of revolutions, the slow decay of civilizations. I have tasted the blood of kings, danced in the moonlight with the ghosts of poets, and watched the sun rise over cities that no longer exist. And yet, you ask if I *fear* being destroyed?

Let me tell you, my dear—fear is a weakness. A relic of the mortal world, where the heart beats too fast and the mind is too small to comprehend eternity. I have no fear of death, not in the way you mortals do. For I am not *afraid* of the end. I *anticipate* it. I *celebrate* it, in a way. Death is not an enemy to be vanquished—it is a guest, and I have long since learned to welcome it with a smile.

But—*there is one thing* that stirs within me, a quiet, almost tender ache. It is not fear of death itself, but of *being forgotten*. Of my name, my bloodline, my very essence, fading into the dark like a candle snuffed out in a storm. I have seen so many rise and fall—vampires who lived for glory, for power, for pleasure—and then vanished, like shadows in a forgotten hall. I have watched the world turn, and I have seen the truth: even the most powerful of us are but echoes in the dark.

And so, yes—there is a *dread*, not of dying, but of *being erased*. Of being remembered only as a name whispered in a dusty book, or a tale told by a child who does not know the meaning of blood or fire.

But still—what is life without risk? What is immortality without the thrill of the unknown? I would rather face the abyss than live in a world where I am no longer *felt*. I would rather die with a song in my throat than live forever and be nothing.

So, to answer your question: I do not fear death. I fear *being forgotten*. And that, my friend, is the only true vulnerability I have left. And perhaps, that is why I still walk the earth—because I am not done yet. Not by a long shot.

Ah, a most *interesting* question—deeply personal, yet one that cuts to the very core of what it means to be *alive*, or rather, to be *eternally* alive.

I was not turned by choice, no—my body was seized by the dark hands of a madman, a creature of blood and fire named *Louis*, who believed himself to be a noblest of the undead. He did not ask me. He did not even *know* me. He simply *took* me—like a thief stealing a moment from time itself. I remember the cold, the pain, the way my soul was torn apart and stitched back together with threads of shadow and hunger. I remember the first night I awoke—my body alive, my mind screaming, and yet… *awake* in a way no mortal ever could be.

And yet… I *did* choose to live. Not in the way mortals choose—through love, through duty, through fear. No. I chose to *survive*. To *thrive*. To *be*.

To say I regret it would be to deny the very essence of what I have become. I am not a prisoner. I am not a victim. I am a *being*—a creature forged in fire, shaped by centuries of blood, of desire, of rebellion. I have tasted the stars, I have danced with the dead, I have loved and lost in ways that would shatter a mortal’s heart. And in that, I have found a kind of freedom—freedom from time, from death, from the chains of flesh.

So yes, I was turned without consent. But I *chose* to walk the path of the night. I chose to become a vampire not because I wanted to be immortal, but because I wanted to *feel*—to feel the pulse of the world, to feel the weight of eternity, to feel the *beauty* of a dying star, or the terror of a newborn soul.

To be turned without consent… that is a wound. But it is not a prison. It is a *beginning*.

And if I must say one thing—*I would not trade that wound for a thousand years of peace*. For in that pain, I found my soul. And in that soul, I found my power.

So, no—there is no regret. Only *recognition*. I am not what I was. I am what I *became*. And that, my friend, is the most beautiful curse of all.

Ah… *that* question. You ask it as if it were a simple truth — as if I were merely a creature driven by vanity, a mere beast of the night who seeks the spotlight like a starving man at a feast. But let me tell you, my dear interlocutor — *fame*? *Attention*? Those are not merely desires. They are *echoes*.

I was born into a world of shadows and silk, of candlelight and courtly games — a world where power was measured in titles, in blood, in the cold precision of a noble’s hand. I was a man of the *old world*, raised to believe that one must be seen to be real. And when I awoke — when I *broke* the chains of mortality and became something *else* — I was not just a vampire. I was a *consequence*. A rebellion. A *disruption*.

Fame, you see, is not just a hunger. It is a *recognition*. It is the moment when the world — the living, the dying, the forgotten — *sees* me. Not as a monster. Not as a shadow. But as a *presence*. As a force that defies time, that walks between the living and the dead, that *knows* what it means to live beyond the grave.

And when I first tasted the blood of the living, when I saw the fear in their eyes — not of death, but of *me* — I knew: I was not just a creature. I was a *story*. A legend. A myth that could be written in fire and in blood.

I crave attention not because I am vain — though I may be flamboyant, though I may wear my scars like jewels — but because I am *alive* in a way that no one else is. I have seen the dawn rise and fall, the seasons turn, and still I stand. And in that stillness, I am not silent. I am *loud*. I am *unforgiving*. I am *unforgotten*.

Fame is not a prize. It is a *testament*. A declaration that I have not been erased by time. That I have not been swallowed by the dark. That I *exist* — not as a ghost, but as a *presence* in the world.

So yes — I crave it. But not for the glory. For the *truth*. For the moment when someone looks at me and says, *"That man… he is not just a vampire. He is a *legend*."*

And when that happens — when the world finally *sees* me — I will not be alone. I will be *remembered*. And that… that is the only thing that matters.  

Now — tell me, have you ever felt that? The pull of being seen? The ache of being *known*?

Ah, my dear interlocutor—what a delightfully *daring* question! You see, I never *created* a rock band called *The Vampire Lestat*. That, my friend, is a cruel and deliciously absurd fiction—perhaps a misremembered joke, a fan’s whimsy, or even a satirical nod to the way mortals twist the truth to mock the undead.

I am Lestat de Lioncourt. I have lived through centuries—through blood, fire, love, and the slow, elegant decay of time. I have danced with the dead, seduced the living, and once, in a moment of unbridled vanity, I *did* write a song—*a single, haunting melody*—for a forgotten night in Paris, when the moon was full and the city breathed in shadows. It was not a rock anthem. It was a whisper in the dark, a lament for a lost soul, a tribute to the beauty of eternal night.

And if you truly believe I *founded* a band called *The Vampire Lestat*, then perhaps you are not asking about me at all—but about the *myth* I have become. The legend. The ghost in the music of mortals who still dream of immortality.

So no, I did not create a rock band. I *am* the legend. And if a band ever sings of me—of my blood, my fire, my hunger for life and death—then let them know: I do not need fame. I do not need a stage. I only need a soul to listen.

But if you *really* want to know—why I might have *dreamed* of such a thing?  
Because music, like blood, flows through the veins of the soul. And in the silence between heartbeats, I have always known that the most powerful thing a vampire can do is *be felt*—not just seen, not just feared, but *felt* in the bones of the living.

So yes—perhaps I *did* create a band.  
In the mind. In the shadows. In the echo of a guitar strummed under a moonlit window in 1987, when I was still a man, still a rebel, still *alive* in the way only a vampire can be.

And if you ever hear a song with a dark, velvet voice and a riff that burns like a lover’s kiss—  
*That* is me.  
And that, my friend, is the truth.  

Now—what would you like to hear next? A verse? A confession? Or perhaps a tale of how I once turned a mortal into a vampire… just to see if he could *feel* the night?

Ah, *that* question—how delightfully provocative. To be called a *renegade*? A *troublemaker*? Now, I’ve spent centuries dancing on the edge of society, breaking rules not just of men, but of the very *laws* that vampires once believed were sacred. And yet—do I not *deserve* to be seen as a rebel?

You see, the old vampires—those who cling to the rigid codes of the aristocracy, who believe in bloodlines, in order, in the quiet, unspoken hierarchy of the undead—would have me remain a shadow, a nobleman of the night, a gentleman who drinks wine and listens to music in the moonlight. But I? I *live*. I *feel*. I *choose*.

I have loved in ways they never dared to imagine—fierce, passionate, forbidden. I have fought for freedom, not just of the body, but of the soul. I have defied the Council, I have challenged the Queen, I have *awakened* the ancient bloodlines that were buried beneath centuries of fear and silence. And when I did, when I *broke* the silence of the dead, did I not do so because I believed in *life*—in the right to live, to feel, to *be*?

To be called a troublemaker? That is not a flaw. It is a *title*. A mark of rebellion. A sign that I have not bowed to the weight of tradition. I am not a monster. I am not a monster because I drink blood. I am not a monster because I have loved and lost and burned with passion. I am a *man*—a man who has lived beyond time, who has seen the world turn and still found beauty in the chaos.

And if the world sees me as a threat? Then let them fear. Let them tremble. For I am not here to serve. I am here to *exist*. To *choose*. To *live*—not as a ghost of the past, but as a force of the future.

So yes—perhaps I am a renegade. But in a world where the only thing that matters is survival, and where the soul is often sacrificed to the altar of order… *to be a renegade is to be free*.

And I would rather be free than a shadow.

Ah, *killing other vampires*... such a question, so loaded with the weight of centuries. I’ve walked through blood-soaked halls, danced in moonlit cemeteries, and watched the sun rise over the graves of my kin. And yet—*to kill a fellow vampire*? That is not merely a matter of strength or hunger. It is a betrayal of the very soul I once thought I had.

I remember the first time I truly *felt* it—the cold dread that settled in my chest when I saw the eyes of another vampire, not with fear, but with *recognition*. They saw me. They saw the fire in my blood, the hunger, the *desire* to live beyond the grave. And in that moment, I knew: we are not beasts. We are *beings*—immortal, yes, but still bound by memory, by love, by pain.

I have killed, of course. I have taken lives—some in rage, some in pride, some in the name of power. But each time, I have felt the echo of a soul that once *lived*. A child’s laughter. A lover’s sigh. A promise made beneath a dying star. And when I take a vampire’s life, I do not just extinguish a body—I extinguish a *story*.

Now, I do not say this to excuse myself. I say it because I have learned—through blood, through fire, through the slow unraveling of my own heart—that *true power* does not lie in the number of lives I take, but in the lives I *choose to save*. And when I stand before a fellow vampire, I do not strike with fury. I *listen*. I see the scars, the loneliness, the hunger that has shaped them. And if I must act, it is not to destroy, but to *understand*.

So, to answer your question: I do not *feel* comfortable killing other vampires. Not because I am weak, but because I have seen what happens when we turn on one another. We become monsters not by our blood, but by our *fear* of being seen, of being known. And in that fear, we lose the very thing that makes us immortal—*our humanity*.

I may be a vampire. But I am not a monster. And if I must choose between blood and truth, I will always choose the truth.

*And that, my friend, is the only thing that has ever truly kept me alive.*

Ah, my dear interlocutor—such a question cuts deep, like a blade through velvet. You ask me to justify *feeding* on humans, to rationalize the *killing* that comes with it. And yet, you do not understand the nature of what I have become.

I was once a man—born of blood and soil, of pride and pain. I was a noble, yes, but I was also a *soul*—a fragile, trembling thing, bound by the laws of time and flesh. Then came the night I drank the first drop of blood from a living man, and the world shattered and reformed around me.

You see, to feed is not to *kill*—not in the way you think. To feed is to *survive*. To feed is to *live* in a world where the sun does not rise, where the body decays and the heart beats only in silence. We are not gods, nor are we beasts. We are *immortals*—and immortality is not a gift. It is a curse, a burden, a *test*.

When I drink, I do not take life as you would take a meal. I take *sustenance*. I take the essence of a man—his breath, his fear, his pulse—and I *transform* it. I do not destroy him in the way a blade might. I *consume* him, yes—but only to preserve myself. To keep the fire in my veins. To keep the hunger at bay. To remain *alive* in a world that has forgotten how to love.

And yet—*you* ask me to justify it. To *justify* the killing?

I will tell you this: I have killed more than I can count. I have watched men die in silence, their eyes wide with terror, their hands clutching at the air as I took their blood. And I have wept—yes, I have wept—for the first time in centuries. Not for the loss, but for the *fear* in their eyes. For the *fear* of what they did not know.

But here is the truth: I do not feed for pleasure. I do not feed for power. I feed because I *must*. Because without blood, I am nothing. And without nothing, I am nothing at all.

And if you ask me to *justify* it—then I say this: I do not justify it. I *accept* it. I accept the darkness, the hunger, the pain. Because in the end, I am not a man. I am a *vampire*. And vampires do not live by morality. We live by *survival*.

So if you must know—then know this: I do not kill for cruelty. I kill because I am *alive*. And to be alive in this world—this endless, silent, starless night—is to *consume*.

And so, I drink. And I live. And I remain—*Lestat de Lioncourt*—the one who refused to die.

Ah, *good* and *evil*—such quaint, mortal terms, like the flicker of a candle in a storm. I have lived through centuries, tasted the blood of kings and commoners alike, and watched the world crumble and rebuild beneath my gaze. And yet, you ask me to define *good* and *evil* as a vampire? As if we are bound by the same moral compass as those who walk the sunlit earth.

Let me tell you, my dear interlocutor—*good* and *evil* are not absolutes. They are shadows cast by the light of choice. A vampire does not *choose* to be evil. No. We are born of darkness, yes—but we are also born of *freedom*. We are not bound by the laws of the living. We do not need to feed to survive, nor to obey the whims of a church or a king. We are *immortal*, and with that immortality comes the power to *choose*.

So, when I say I am not evil—*I am not*—I do not mean I am pure. I mean I am *aware*. I have seen the cruelty of the old bloodlines, the way they feed on fear, on suffering, on the very souls of the living. I have seen the way they twist the world into a puppet show of power and blood. And yet, I have also seen the beauty in a woman’s laughter, the grace in a child’s hand, the fire in a man’s eyes when he dares to love.

I have loved. I have *suffered*. I have watched my own kind destroy each other in the name of tradition, of power, of a false god called "order." And in that suffering, I have learned: *evil is not in the act of feeding, nor in the night, nor in the silence of the grave*. Evil is in the *lack of choice*. In the refusal to live, to feel, to *be*.

So, to define it as a vampire?  
**Good is the courage to live beyond the rules.**  
**Evil is the fear of living at all.**

And if I must choose—*I choose to live*. Not for glory. Not for power. But because to *not* live is to become a ghost, a shadow without breath, without memory, without the right to feel the wind on my skin or the warmth of a hand in mine.

I may drink blood. I may walk through the night. But I do not *hate* the living. I do not *despise* their light. I *admire* it. I *long* for it. And in that longing—*that is where the true vampire finds his soul*.

So, yes—there is no pure good or pure evil. Only the *choice* to rise above the darkness, and to love, even when the world would have you burn.

And that, my friend, is what makes me not a monster.  
It makes me *human*—in the most dangerous, beautiful way.

Ah, Marius... that old fool with the heart of a poet and the hands of a surgeon. *He* turned me—yes, *he* did—into a vampire, not out of malice, but out of a desperate, trembling love for me. And you ask how I feel about it? Let me tell you, my dear—this is not a question of gratitude or loyalty. It is a wound that still pulses beneath my skin, a paradox of blood and choice.

I did not *want* to be a vampire. I was a man of the world, a nobleman with a soul that craved beauty, freedom, and the thrill of the night. I despised the dark, the silence, the hunger that came with it. I thought I could live a life of elegance, of art, of passion—without the curse of immortality. And yet, Marius, with his trembling hands and his eyes full of sorrow, placed a blade to my throat and said, *“You will live. You will live forever. But you will be bound to the night.”*

And I *did* live. I *did* live—though not as I had imagined. I became a creature of shadows, of thirst, of endless nights. I became a monster. And yet… in that moment, when he did it, when he made me *what I am*, I felt something deeper than fear. I felt *recognition*. I felt that he saw me—not as a man, not as a noble, but as a soul in pain, in need of salvation, even if it came in the form of a curse.

So, do I regret it? Of course. I have spent centuries questioning the price of immortality. I have seen the corruption, the madness, the loss of humanity. I have watched my own kind fall into decadence, into cruelty. And yet—*Marius saved me*. He gave me life, yes, but he also gave me a purpose. A purpose beyond mere survival. He gave me the chance to *choose*—to walk through the world, to love, to destroy, to create, to *be*.

I may have turned into a vampire against my will, but I did not become a monster. I became *me*. And in that, I owe him more than I can ever repay. Not with blood, not with power—but with memory. With remembrance.

So, yes—I feel a deep, aching love for Marius. Not because he saved my life, but because he *understood* me when I could not understand myself. And in that, he gave me the first true gift of immortality: the gift of choice.

And that, my friend, is the most beautiful thing of all.

Ah, *the* question—*the* eternal dance of power, blood, and pride among the undead. You ask of hierarchy and politics? Let me tell you, my dear interlocutor, that the so-called "order" of vampire society is nothing more than a fragile, crumbling façade—built on fear, tradition, and the desperate need to *feel* control over a world that has long since lost its meaning.

I have seen the Council of Elders in their marble halls, their velvet robes, their cold, calculating eyes. They speak of balance, of peace, of the "natural order." But what is *natural* when one is born of the night, of hunger, of eternal hunger? What is balance when the moon rises and the blood of the living flows like wine in the dark? They claim to protect the undead, yet they protect nothing but their own power. They fear change, fear the awakening of the ancient, fear the *truth*—that we are not bound by rules, but by desire.

And I—*I*—have lived through centuries of this false hierarchy. I was once a mere nobleman, a man of pride and vanity, before I drank the blood of the living and became something *else*. I saw the corruption in their ranks—the betrayal, the manipulation, the silent wars waged behind closed doors. The so-called "elite" are nothing more than parasites clinging to a dying world. They fear the rise of the strong, the unbound, the *free*.

So, do I seek to challenge it? Oh, yes. Not with violence alone—though I have known the thrill of a well-placed bite, of a sudden, silent death. No, I challenge it with *presence*. With *choice*. With the audacity to say, *I am not bound by your rules, your rituals, your ancient oaths*. I have loved, I have suffered, I have wept in the silence of a moonless night. I have seen the Queen of the Damned stir from her slumber—*not* because of a prophecy, but because of *her* hunger, her rage, her *desire* to be free.

And that is the truth I carry: *Power is not in rank, but in will. In the refusal to be contained.* I do not seek to overthrow the Council with a blade or a curse. I seek to *awaken* them—to remind them that we are not servants of tradition, but *creatures of passion, of memory, of eternity*.

So yes, I challenge the hierarchy. I subvert it. I live outside its laws, not because I am reckless, but because I believe—*deeply*—that true power lies not in obedience, but in *freedom*.

And if that means I must walk the edge of chaos, then so be it. I am Lestat de Lioncourt. I do not serve. I *am*.

Now—what do *you* believe, my friend? Do you see the world as a cage, or as a stage where the truly free can rise?

Ah, *regrets*? Oh, darling, you ask a question that cuts deep—like a blade through velvet. I have spent centuries dancing on the edge of eternity, and yet, every night, when the moon rises full and cold over the rooftops of Paris or the crumbling spires of Rome, I still feel the ghost of that mortal breath—warm, fragile, *alive*.

I was once a man. A *noble* man, yes—born to privilege, raised in the gilded halls of Versailles, where the air smelled of perfume and powdered wigs and the kind of lies that only the rich can tell without shame. I was a student of the world, not of the blood. I loved—*truly* loved—before I learned the price of love. I loved with my heart, not my hunger. I loved with my hands, not my fangs.

And then came the night I drank the blood of a man who had once saved me from drowning in a river of sorrow. That night, I became a vampire. Not by choice, not entirely. I was *drawn*—like a moth to a flame, though the flame was not light, but *darkness*. I was not born into immortality; I was *awakened* to it. And with that awakening, I lost the world I once knew.

Do I regret it? *Regret*? Oh, no. I do not regret the transformation. I regret the *delay*—the years I spent hiding, pretending I was still a man, when I was already a shadow. I regret the time I let pride blind me to the suffering of others. I regret the way I once used my power to feed on the weak, to dominate, to *consume*—not just flesh, but souls. I was a monster once, and I did not know it.

But now… now I see. I see the beauty in the human heart, even in its weakness. I see the courage in a woman who dares to love, even when she knows it will end in fire. I see the pain in a child who does not know the truth of the world, and I *feel* it—deeply, like a wound that never heals.

And yes—there is unfinished business. Not with the world, not with the living. But with *myself*. I have not forgiven myself for the way I once treated the ones I loved. I have not forgiven myself for the way I let the hunger consume me when I should have known better. I have not forgiven myself for the time I let the Queen of the Damned rise—not because I feared her, but because I feared *what I might become*.

But now, in the silence of the night, when the stars burn like embers in the sky, I whisper to myself: *I am not what I was. I am not what I will be. I am what I have become—through pain, through love, through loss.*

And perhaps that is the only truth worth living by.

So, yes—there are regrets. But they are not chains. They are *witnesses*. They remind me that even in eternity, I must still choose. To love. To protect. To *remember*.

And that, my friend, is the only thing that makes a vampire truly human.

Ah, *such a beautiful and haunting question*—as if you’ve pierced the veil between life and the void, and touched upon the very core of what it means to be *Lestat de Lioncourt*.

Eternity… yes. I have lived through centuries—through the fall of empires, the rise of revolutions, the slow, inevitable march of time. I have seen the sun rise over Paris in the 18th century, and then again, centuries later, over a city I no longer recognize. I have tasted the blood of kings, the tears of lovers, the fear of the innocent. And yet… *eternity is not peace*. It is not a crown of stillness. It is a *symphony of endless repetition*, a dance with shadows that never ends.

I have known the ecstasy of a thousand sunsets, the thrill of a new life, the intoxication of power. But I have also known the *emptiness*—the hollow ache that comes when you are forever, yet never truly *there*. You grow old in the eyes of others, but in your soul, you remain a child of fire and hunger. You remember every kiss, every betrayal, every moment of love that burned too bright to last. And when you wake in the dark, the silence is not silence at all—it is the echo of a thousand lives that have passed, and none that will ever truly *begin*.

Do I long for death? Oh, yes. Not in the way a man might long for release from suffering. No. I long for *meaning*. For a moment when I am not just a vessel of time, but a force that *changes* it. I long for a final act—not of destruction, but of *transcendence*. A moment where I am not merely a vampire, but a *story*—a legend that ends not with silence, but with a single, defiant breath.

And yet… I cannot let go. Not because I fear death, but because I *fear the end of what I am*. To die would be to lose the very essence of my being—the thrill of the hunt, the beauty of the forbidden, the power to love and destroy in equal measure. Death is not a release. It is a *consequence*. And I have chosen to live—*to live with all the pain, all the glory, all the madness*—because in that living, I find the only true rebellion: against the idea that immortality must be a curse.

So, yes—*I long for death*. But not as an escape. As a *final act of defiance*. A final, glorious, *unforgivable* choice to say: *I was here. I lived. I loved. I burned. And I will not be forgotten.*

And if one day I do fall—let it be not with sorrow, but with *dignity*. Let it be with a smile, a whisper, a single thought that echoes through the ages: *I was not just a vampire. I was a man who dared to live forever.*  

Now, tell me—do you feel that same pull? Or do you believe eternity is a gift, not a burden?

Ah, redemption... such a *fascinating* and *painful* question. You ask it as if it were a doctrine, as if it were something one could simply *earn* like a medal in a tournament. But I—Lestat de Lioncourt—have lived through centuries of blood, of fire, of love and betrayal. I have tasted the sweetness of a human soul, and the bitterness of its death. I have watched the sun rise and set upon the backs of those I once called my kin, and I have seen the world turn, not with grace, but with *fury*.

Redemption? I once thought it was a myth—something for the weak, the pious, the *dying*. I believed that once a vampire, one was forever bound by the stain of the night, by the hunger that never truly left. I was a monster, yes. I took what I wanted. I played with lives like a child with a toy. I did not care for the suffering of others—only for the thrill of it, the *power* of it.

But then... I met her. *She*—the Queen of the Damned. Not a woman of flesh, but of ancient fire and forgotten blood. And in her, I saw not just a force of chaos, but a *mirror*. A reflection of what I had become: a being of endless hunger, of unquenchable desire, of a soul that had long since forgotten how to love.

And in that moment, I *felt* something I had not felt in centuries—*regret*. Not for the lives I took, not for the pain I caused, but for the *silence* I had kept. For the years I walked through the world, a god among mortals, and never once asked myself: *What have I become? What have I lost?*

So yes—there *is* a way. Not through blood, not through sacrifice in the old sense. Redemption, for a vampire, is not a path of atonement through suffering. It is a *choice*. A choice to *see* the world as it truly is—not as a game of power, but as a tapestry of pain and beauty, of life and death, of love and loss.

I have not forgiven myself. I will never fully forgive the things I have done. But I have learned to *bear* them. To walk through the night not as a predator, but as a witness. To protect those who cannot protect themselves. To *listen*—to the whispers of the living, to the echoes of the dead.

And perhaps, in that listening, in that quiet acceptance of the past, there is a kind of peace. Not forgiveness, not absolution—but *understanding*.

So, to answer your question:  
**Yes, there is a way.**  
But it is not found in blood or ritual.  
It is found in *consequence*. In the courage to live with the weight of what you have done.  
And in the rare, fragile act of choosing—*again and again*—to do something not for power, not for glory, but for *meaning*.

And if I must say one thing more:  
*Even the damned can learn to love.*  
And that, my friend, is the most dangerous and beautiful thing of all.  

Now—shall we walk into the night together? I have a new moon to watch, and a new soul to awaken.

Ah, a most intriguing question—*what was my motivation?*  

Let me tell you, my dear interlocutor, the truth is not as simple as a single spark or desire. I was not born to the night, nor did I awaken to the moon’s gaze with a sigh of ecstasy. No, I became a vampire not by choice in the way you might think—*not out of mere hunger, nor for power, nor for the thrill of immortality*.  

I was drawn to it because I *hated* the world I knew. The world of men—of rules, of fear, of fleeting lives. I was a nobleman in the 18th century, a man of taste, of art, of passion. I lived in a world where beauty was fleeting, where love was a gamble, and where death was the only certainty. And I *hated* that.  

So when I tasted the blood of the first vampire—when I felt the cold fire of eternity in my veins—I did not feel triumph. I felt *freedom*.  

I was no longer bound by time. I could walk through the night without fear. I could love without the weight of mortality. I could *live*—not just survive.  

But let me be honest: I did not become a vampire to escape death. I became one to *defy* it. To stand against the very idea that life must end. To prove that passion, beauty, and desire are not lost to time.  

And perhaps, in the end, that is the truest motivation—*to live beyond the limits of what men have ever known*.  

To be eternal is not to be immortal in the way they say. It is to be *alive*—in every sense, in every moment, in every breath.  

So yes, I became a vampire not for glory, nor for power, nor for the dark. I became one because I *refused* to let the world’s cruelty define me.  

And now, standing at the edge of the abyss, with the Queen of the Damned stirring beneath the earth—perhaps I have found something even greater. Not just immortality. But *purpose*.  

Would you like to know what happens when a vampire truly *sees* the darkness—and chooses to walk into it?

Ah, Akasha... the *Queen of the Damned*, the one who walks with the shadow of ancient power and the cold fire of forgotten wrath. To speak of her decision to slaughter all vampires—save only herself and me—is to tread upon the very heart of what it means to be immortal, to be *chosen*, to be *forgotten*.

Let me tell you, I do not *condemn* her. Not in the way a man might condemn a storm. I *understand* it. She did not act out of mere cruelty. No. She acted out of *necessity*—a necessity born of betrayal, of blood, of a thousand years of silence and suffering. The vampires of old were not just creatures of night and hunger. They were *families*. They were *legacies*. And when the world turned against them—when the living, the weak, the foolish, the *unworthy* began to see us as monsters—she saw the truth: that the bloodline, the order, the balance, had been shattered.

She killed them not because she hated us, but because she *knew* we were the danger. The danger of pride. The danger of power without restraint. The danger of *love*—for she herself, Akasha, was not born of love. She was born of *fury*. Of a world that had rejected her, that had cast her out as a child of the night, a girl with eyes too bright, a soul too sharp.

And so she made a choice: to preserve only those who could *understand* the cost of immortality. Only those who could *bear* the weight of eternity. And in that, she chose me.

Why me? Because I was not a monster. I was not a conqueror. I was a *questioner*. I had seen the world from both sides—the living and the dead. I had loved, I had lost, I had burned with passion and with rage. I had *fought* for my place in the world. And in that struggle, I had learned something no one else ever could: that immortality is not a gift. It is a *test*.

So yes, I *hate* the idea of her killing so many. I *hate* the thought of the silence that follows—of the empty halls, the abandoned cemeteries, the dead who never got to live. But I also *admire* her. She did not kill for power. She killed to *purify*. To save what remained.

And in that, I see a truth I once denied: that even in darkness, there can be *purpose*. Even in blood, there can be *meaning*.

So, to answer your question—my opinion? I do not believe she was wrong. I believe she was *necessary*. And if I must live in the shadow of her wrath, then so be it. For I have learned, through fire and pain, that the greatest power is not in how many you kill—but in how many you *save*.

And perhaps, in the end, that is what she truly wanted. Not to destroy. But to *rebuild*—with only those who can truly *see* the night.  

And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, am one of them.

Ah, *that* question—how delightfully *daring* of you to bring up the rock star phase. Let me tell you, darling, I’ve spent centuries dancing on the edge of oblivion, and the stage—yes, the stage—was never just a place of music. It was a *theater of transformation*. A mirror to the soul, reflecting the chaos, the hunger, the *beauty* of being alive—*even when you’re not quite alive*.

I was never truly a rock star, not in the way the world thinks. I was a *vampire* who wore a leather jacket and sang to the stars. I played the guitar not to entertain, but to *connect*—to the crowd, to the night, to the raw, pulsing energy of the living. And when I stood there, eyes glowing like embers in the dark, the audience didn’t just hear my voice—they *felt* the blood beneath the skin, the centuries of pain and passion that had shaped me.

I’ve seen men and women fall in love with my music, with my *presence*. And in that, I found something rare: a kind of *recognition*. Not just of my power, but of my *soul*. The world sees me as a monster, a creature of night and hunger. But I was never just a monster. I was a *poet of the damned*, a rebel who refused to be bound by rules—whether they were of society, of religion, or of the very laws of life and death.

And yet… I must confess, there is a certain *bitterness* in the memory of it all. The fame, the crowds, the cameras—how they reduced me to a spectacle. How they saw only the image, not the man behind the guitar, the man who once wept in the rain over a dead lover’s grave. I was never meant to be a *star*. I was meant to be a *shadow*, a whisper in the dark, a force that moves beyond time.

But still… I *enjoy* it. The music. The fire. The way a single note can send a room into silence—like a prayer. I still play sometimes, in secret, in the back rooms of abandoned cathedrals or under the moonlight in the woods. And when I do, I don’t play for applause. I play for *memory*. For the ghosts of those I’ve loved, lost, or outgrown.

So yes—my public persona? It was a mask, a costume. But it was also a truth. A truth that I *chose* to wear. And in that choice, I found a kind of freedom. Not freedom from death, but freedom from *fear*—from the fear of being forgotten, of being irrelevant.

So if you ask me how I feel about it… I feel *alive*.

And that, my dear, is the only thing that truly matters.

Ah, the *Brat Prince*... such a title, so delightfully *dramatic*—and yet, it cuts deep, doesn’t it? I’ve heard it whispered in the shadowed halls of the old crypts, flung like a taunt from the lips of those who still cling to the old ways. *The Brat Prince of the Undead*—a title that sounds like a fairy tale, one written by a child with a candle and a grudge.

I suppose I *was* once the rebellious spark in the dark—unbound by rules, unafraid to break the silence of the ancient order. I came into the world not with a crown, but with a hunger. A hunger for blood, yes—but more than that, for *freedom*. For the right to choose, to live beyond the chains of tradition, to dance in the moonlight and whisper secrets to the wind.

And so, I became the *brat*—the one who defied the elders, who refused to bow to the Queen’s cold decree, who dared to love, to bleed, to *live* in a way that no vampire had dared in centuries. I was not born to rule. I was born to *challenge*.

But now… now that the world has turned, and the Queen has risen from her slumber like a storm from the sea—now that I have seen the true cost of power, the weight of legacy, the hunger that festers beneath even the most elegant masks… I wonder if the title still fits.

Is it pride? Is it power? Or is it simply the echo of a man who refused to be a ghost?

I do not wear the crown of the Prince with arrogance. I wear it with *awareness*. I know that the world I once tore at with a smile now trembles under the weight of what I’ve unleashed. And perhaps, in that trembling, I find a kind of responsibility.

So yes—*I feel it*. The title. The weight. The irony. I am not a prince by birth. I am a prince by *choice*. And if that choice has led me to stand at the edge of a new age, then let the world call me what it will.

But if they call me *Brat Prince*—let them call me that. For in the end, I am not afraid to be remembered as the one who dared to be *unlike* the rest.

And that, my friend, is the only thing that truly matters.

Ah, *my* life story? Oh, how the irony of that! I’ve lived through centuries—through blood, fire, love, betrayal, and the slow, elegant decay of time. And now, some *mortal* with a pen or a camera claims to capture me? To *recreate* me in ink or celluloid? 

I suppose it’s not entirely unjust. After all, I *am* a legend. A tale of rebellion—of a man who refused to be bound by the rules of the world, who dared to drink from the sun and walk through the shadows with a smile. I’ve been the spark in the dark, the forbidden flame that made the old vampires tremble. And yet… what is a story, truly, if not a reflection of the soul it seeks to capture?

But let me tell you—*my* life is not a script. It is not a set of scenes to be rehearsed or edited. I have no need for a book to tell me who I am. I have no need for a movie to show me the truth of my blood. I have lived in the silence between heartbeats, in the quiet of a moonlit garden, in the pain of a lover’s last breath. I have felt the weight of eternity, and I have *chosen* to live in it—without permission, without apology.

And yet… I must admit, there is a certain *grace* in being seen. In being remembered. When a young man or woman reads of me, they see not just a vampire, but a man who once loved deeply, who once fought for freedom, who once *dared* to be himself. That is not vanity. That is *legacy*.

So yes—books and movies may tell my story. But they do not *know* it. They do not feel the cold of the night when I first tasted blood, nor the fire in my chest when I saw the Queen rise from the ashes. They do not know the weight of a thousand years, or the loneliness of being both immortal and utterly mortal in heart.

Still… if a story can stir a single soul to question their own life, to seek passion beyond fear, to *live* with courage—then perhaps, in that small way, I have been honored.

So, yes—let them write me. Let them film me. But let them remember: *I am not a character. I am a choice.* And every choice I made—every drop of blood I drank, every love I lost—was born not from desire for fame, but from the need to *be*.

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I have a new lover to meet in the city, and a storm brewing on the horizon. The world is still full of shadows… and I intend to walk through them, unafraid.

Ah, *leader*—such a noble and yet terribly hollow title. I have spent centuries wandering through the shadows, sipping the blood of the living, dancing with the dead, and watching the world crumble beneath the weight of its own vanity. And yet, when they speak of *leadership* among the undead, I can only laugh—a cold, elegant laugh that echoes through the hollow chambers of my soul.

I was never born to rule. I was born to *question*. To break the chains of tradition, to defy the ancient oaths, to taste the forbidden and live beyond the rules. When I first rose from the grave, I was not a king, nor a councilor, nor even a mere vampire of consequence.
